I've done and read a fair bit about quantum physics, all time existing at once is not a problem for me- it is merely an additional dimension. However because of this, things are always the same at each time, 4 inutes in the future won't be any different if you could see it now as if the saem time was 4 minutes in the past.
 Seeing the future and knowing it is different, if you know the future then it can not change. You make no choices but feel you have (as what you consider choice is just the brain working out which thing it will do, it is a machine, set it up in a certain way and feed the same information in and it will always react the same way). Everyone makes their own choice, but they would never have made a different one (well they may have but not often enough for it to have an effect on the majority of the rest of the choices consquences- if playing with quantum choice then one of the choices might effect a consquence of a different choice- essentially in one universe the paritcle moves through an open gap, whereas in the a door has been put i the way. One object goes through the gap and the other can not, however sometimes the object that went through the gap will appear on the otherside of the door as it replaces the object that did not in a different place. The object both went and did not go through the gap at the same time, this isn't a case where we can't tell if it did or not, it did both. This is the schrodingers cat experiment though it is often misunderstood.)

this thread sure bounced around from whether life is for good or bad, to whether we have free will, to whether we should be at war...
 
 anyway, getting back to the real topic
 
 i believe that life is what you choose to make it to be, both by your physical actions and by your mental perspective. 
 
 look at how perspective changes life as a whole
 
 scenario: say you get caught stealing office supplies and you lose you job.
 
 1. "hey, i never liked this job anyway, my boss sucks. ill find something better"
 2. "hmmm... I got to be smarter when i steal office supplies so next time i wont get caught"
 3. "man, my life was heading down the wrong path. i need to stop stealing and get myself in order"
 4. "noooo! you think you can fire me???? i'll come back in here on monday and kill everybody then kill myself!"
 
 whether losing your job is a good thing or a bad thing (as well as most everything in life) always comes down to your own perspective and the actions you choose to commit as a result
 
 thats my philosophy anyway

 I like your example.... I believe that my degree of success and/or happiness is mostly a result of how I cope with life's ups and downs. I now realize that one of the only things that I can control is how I choose to REACT to things. By keeping an attitude of gratitude (= positive perspective a.k.a. glass is half full) I can - and do - handle events in a way that result in a minimum of stress. Obviously, some things can't be viewed through "rose colored glasses" all the time; however, since I choose not to concentrate on the negatives of day-to-day life, I can better handle life's true tragedies.
 
 As for your example, I choose to recognize that stealing was a poor choice (not because I got caught, but because the experience did not reenforce my set of values {esteem}) and I recognize that I can learn and grow from the experience. The negative experience becomes a positive one because I know I have gained knowledge/understanding.
 
 **If I do not learn & adapt as a result of a negative experience, then the negative aspects become amplified and (more) regettable. **
 
 regards.....
 
 P. S. Sorry for any spelling misakes (is there a spell checker tool here?)
